DataElement.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Diagnostic Imaging Negative Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Assessment Date
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the date a MRI or CT scan was negative for brain metastases.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Diagnostic Imaging Negative Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body, or computed tomographic (CT) scan, a method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis, being negative for cancer that has spread from the original (primary) tumor to the brain.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Diagnostic Imaging
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Non-invasive method of demonstrating internal anatomy based on the principle that atomic nuclei in a strong magnetic field absorb pulses of radiofrequency energy and emit them as radiowaves which can be reconstructed into computerized images. The concept includes proton spin tomographic techniques.:Tomography using x-ray transmission and a computer algorithm to reconstruct the image.:Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.
Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.

Property.preferredName: Negative Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Assessment
Property.preferredDefinition: Negative; not indicating the presence of microorganisms or disease or a specific condition.:The spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain. The most common primary tumors metastatic to brain include lung cancer(adenosquamous and small cell especially), breast cancer, melanoma, renal cancer and colon cancer. Metastases are frequently found at the grey/white junction. They are usually well demarcated from the brain parenchyma. The majority of metastases (greater than 75%) are found supratentorially with the minority (less than 10%) found in the brainstem. The patients present with signs and symptoms referable to either increased intracranial pressure or focal pathology. A contrast enhanced MRI will give the best view of suspected metastatic cancers. Therapy for the metastatic cancer is based upon the therapy that would be or has been given to the primary cancer. In any event corticosteroids can be useful for reduction of patients' symptoms. (Kaye, Laws Brain Tumors Churchill Livingstone 1995):Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)

Concepts.definition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).

A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The date on which an observation was made or an event occurred.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: a particular day specified as the time something has, or will, happen.

Concepts.definition: The particular day, month and year an event has happened or will happen.
